title: Confusion in `times.js`
body:
Hello,

I'm confused about the following code in `times.js`
```javascript
index = MAX_ARRAY_LENGTH
n -= MAX_ARRAY_LENGTH
while (++index < n) {
  iteratee(index)
}
```

Now, assuming the first param is between `MAX_ARRAY_LENGTH ` and `MAX_SAFE_INTEGER `. For better debugging, I change MAX_ARRAY_LENGTH to `5`. 

Then, I run this
```javascript
const MAX_ARRAY_LENGTH = 5

function times(n, iteratee) {
  // as before
}

let i = 0
const result = times(15, () => i++)
console.log(result) // [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]
console.log(i) // 9
```

What is expected in **my opinion**?

The `result` should be `[0, 1, 2, 3, 4]`.
The `iteratee` should be executed 15 times.
The variable `i` should be 15.

What is actually happening?
The result is `[0, 1, 2, 3, 4]` as expected.
The `iteratee` **only** executed 9 times.
The value of variable `i` finally becomes 9.

**Additional guess**
If I change the code on the top like this
```javascript
index = MAX_ARRAY_LENGTH
while (++index <= n) {
  iteratee(index)
}
```
This has met my expectations.😂😂😂

I‘ll be very grateful if someone can answer my question.😃

title: Lodash v5 approach to ESM.
body:
I'm labelling this `question` since we don't have a `discussion` tag _(no need to create one for this)_.

Since [`esm`](https://github.com/standard-things/esm) is stable, I want to start moving to Lodash v5.

The plan for Lodash v5 was always that it would be ESM but the execution of it wasn't clear until now.
With Lodash v5 taking a dependency on `esm` we can make an ESM entry point that imports all modules available to CJS. The individual cherry-pickable modules though would be ESM and would require folks to use a loader, like `esm`, a bundler, or the package.json "mode" option _(if and when that is available)_. Since the cherry-pickable modules will be ESM no additional work will be needed for bundlers like webpack, rollup, and parcel.

So this means folks using just CJS would get
```js
const _ = require("lodash")
```
but if they wanted cherry-picked forms they'd need to write ESM
```js
import { pick } from "lodash"
// or
import pick from "lodash/pick"
```
and use a bundler or [`esm`](https://github.com/standard-things/esm).

title: Default orders for orderBy when ordering by multiple iteratees.
body:
Unless I'm mistaken, the [current behaviour](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/orderBy.js) of orderBy makes you set an order for each iteratees you are ordering by, there is no default option when you want the same order for all.

This makes you have to write:

` orderBy(arr, ['it1', 'it2', 'it3'], ['desc', 'desc', desc']);`

When you could just write:

` orderBy(arr, ['it1', 'it2', 'it3'], 'desc');`

And have this:

```
if (!Array.isArray(orders)) {
   orders = orders == null ? [] : [orders]
}
```

Be:

```
if (!Array.isArray(orders)) {
   orders = orders == null ? [] : [...Array(iteratees.length)].map(arrPos => orders);
}
```


title: [Feature Request] [Suggestion] : String split by character count.
lodash.pick behavior differs from lodash/pick
body:
I'm sure this is the result of something dumb I've done.

It was my understanding that `lodash.pick` behaved the same as `lodash/pick`; I'm observing otherwise on `4.4.0`:
```js
// index.js
const _pick = require("lodash/pick")
const pick = require("lodash.pick")

const ORIGINAL = {
  one: 1,
  and: {
    two: "2",
    three: 3,
    another: {
      four: 4
    }
  }
}

const PATHS = ["one", "and.three", "and.another.four"]

console.log(_pick(ORIGINAL, PATHS))
console.log(pick(ORIGINAL, PATHS))
```

Produces:
```sh
❯ node index.js
{ one: 1, and: { three: 3, another: { four: 4 } } }
{ one: 1 }
```

Repro ==> https://gist.github.com/knksmith57/a43ed55b52212e0974ae1cae69fa9b3c

Environment:
```
❯ node -v
v8.9.4

❯ npm -v
5.7.1

❯ npm ls lodash.pick lodash
/Users/kbsmith/Projects/scratch/lodash-pick-differences
├── lodash@4.17.5
└── lodash.pick@4.4.0
```

Please let me know if there's any additional info I can provide. Thanks!

title: Avoid creating sparse arrays in v8
body:
According to [an article last year](https://v8project.blogspot.com/2017/09/elements-kinds-in-v8.html), `new Array( length > 0 )` and `Array.prototype.map` create sparse arrays in v8, which causes deopts when working with common array types. It would be interesting to investigate changing out all of the `Array(length)` creations to simply `[]` to avoid this deopt. Having lodash's `map` produce a dense array might give it a leg up on native `map` in some cases.

Also curious if other engines deopt in a similar way.

title: Inconsistent sort order for NaN values across browsers
body:
**Lodash version:** 4.17.5
**Minimal reproducible example:**
```javascript
_.sortBy([1, 2, 3], function(x){ return NaN; });
```
**Result in IE11 and Edge (v 41):**
```javascript
[1, 2, 3]
```
**Result in Chrome (v 65) and FF (dev edition, v 60):**
```javascript
[3, 2, 1]
```

(all tests were run in lodash.com/docs on Windows 10)

I’m not sure what the intended behavior here is or if the sort order for `NaN`s is even “guaranteed”.
#1482 seems to indicate that `[3, 2, 1]` would be expected here.

title: forEach can exit loop? 😕
body:
It feels like you are trying to mimic some of the core vanilla js functions like Array#forEach

You have renamed `.each` to `.forEach` so... and done so many other simular vanilla js apis

> https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.5#forEach
> 
> Iteratee functions may exit iteration early by explicitly returning false.

I feel like `_.some()` should be used instead if you intend to exit the loop early.

unlike Array#forEach it can never exit the loop, so this was somewhat unexpected to me

Now with more newer syntax as shorthanded array function being used more often you might not explicit mean to return something that could potentially return a `false` value and exit the loop

```js
// Dose something that might or might not return a false value
function doSomething(item) {
  return false
}

_.forEach(array, item => doSomething(item))
_.forEach(array, item => { doSomething(item) }) // what you actually meant to do...
```

---

I'm one of the guys that try to convert lodash function into vanilla js function whenever i can or see something that don't necessary need the hole lodash library. so Array#forEach and lodash#forEach is not one way korrelation in that way, you are doing more then what Array#forEach are able to do.

I know it's hard to make breaking changes, So I don't really expect any changes in the api. Maybe you will reconsider... how knows? 
But maybe you will make some changes in the documentation at least and say that it's better to use `_.some()` to break the loop?

title: Packaging tests
body:
Hi, I contribute to [Mixxx](https://www.mixxx.org/), an open-source Dj software. We ship a custom build of lodash so our users can use it in their midi controller scripts. Our midi controller scripting engine is based on QtScript, which in turn is based on ECMAScript.

Currently our custom build just includes the assign function. We now want to ship a complete lodash build, however we would like to test lodash in our environment.

It's super easy for me to generate a build with lodash-cli. Is there a way to package test/test.js with its dependencies in a similar way? Can the tests even run outside a browser or node?

title: memoize cache requires clear() method; is this intended or a mistake?
body:
Documentation for the `cache` of a memoized function says that the cache must implement a `clear()` method.  ECMAScript `WeakMaps` no longer have that method, so they technically can't be used as a memoize cache.  Also, the lodash source code doesn't call `clear()` anywhere.  Is this requirement intentional, or an oversight in the documentation?

If lodash has no intention of requiring a `clear()` method in the future, the requirement should be removed from the docs.  Also, I can remove the requirement from [@types/lodash](npm.im/@types/lodash).

### References:

https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.5#memoize
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/WeakMap/clear
https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/master/types/lodash/common/function.d.ts#L697-L699
https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/master/types/lodash/common/common.d.ts#L154-L157

title: internal: use util.types to migrate DEP0103 in Node.js
body:
- Use require('util').types instead of using process.binding('util')
  to get the type checking helpers
- Rename nodeUtil to nodeTypes since that is what it is for

Refs: https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/18415

Here is what I used to test this script:

arr.js

```js
import isArrayBuffer from './isArrayBuffer.js'
import isDate from './isDate.js'
import isMap from './isMap.js'
import isRegExp from './isRegExp.js'
import isSet from './isSet.js'
import isTypedArray from './isTypedArray.js'

const arr = [
  isArrayBuffer(new Uint8Array().buffer),
  isDate(new Date()),
  isMap(new Map()),
  isRegExp(/test/),
  isSet(new Set()),
  isTypedArray(new Uint8Array())
]

export default arr
```

test.js

```js
'use strict';
const a = require('./bundle');
console.log(a);
```

```bash
wget https://nodejs.org/download/nightly/v10.0.0-nightly20180322e714da6f0a/node-v10.0.0-nightly20180322e714da6f0a-darwin-x64.tar.xz
tar xf node-v10.0.0-nightly20180322e714da6f0a-darwin-x64.tar.xz

git checkout master
rollup arr.js --output.format cjs --output.file bundle.js
node-v10.0.0-nightly20180322e714da6f0a-darwin-x64/bin/node --pending-deprecation --trace-warnings test.js
# [ true, true, true, true, true, true ]
# [DEP0103] DeprecationWarning: Accessing native typechecking bindings of Node directly is deprecated. Please use `util.types.isArrayBuffer` instead.

git checkout node-dep-0103
rollup arr.js --output.format cjs --output.file bundle.js
node-v10.0.0-nightly20180322e714da6f0a-darwin-x64/bin/node --pending-deprecation --trace-warnings test.js
# [ true, true, true, true, true, true ]
# no warnings
```

title: unset array items without leaving a null value behind
_.defaultsDeep and arrays with different lengths
body:
Hi Lodash team!

I had a question on how _.defaultsDeep works using arrays with different lengths.

Lodash version - 4.17.5 (latest)

For example

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

**code snippet 1:**
`_.defaultsDeep({
    sources: ["a"],
    test: {
        abcd: ["abc"]
    }
}, {
    sources: ["a", "b"],
    test: {
        abcd: ["abc", "defa"]
    }
});`

outputs `{sources: ["a", "b"], test: { abcd: ["abc", "defa"] } }`

note: here both source and default array had the **different** lengths

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

**code snippet 2:**
`_.defaultsDeep({sources: ["a"], test: { abcd: ["abc", "cde"] } }, {sources: ["b"], test: { abcd: ["abc", "defa"] } });`

outputs `{sources: ["a"], test: { abcd: ["abc", "cde"] } }`

note: here both source and default array had the **same** length

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The observation is if both the arrays are not of the same length, lodash is overriding with the defaults, but if arrays are of the same length, the defaults are not being assigned.

For code snippet 1, the expected output was `{sources: ["a"], test: { abcd: ["abc"] } }``.

Thanks for any help!

title: Proposition: _.count
body: I found myself wanting to count how many members of a collection matched a predicate, and the first natural thing that came to mind was `_.count`. To my surprise, it does not exist (or it has a different name but browsing the doc didn't bring anything), so I resorted to `_.size(_.filter(coll, predicate)`, but I think `count` could be a useful addition to lodash.

title: when use function has judge array
[Question] How can I get a custom build including `baseDifference`?
lazyRange
body:
Hey there!

I was wondering if the lodash team would be interested in having a `lazyRange` function, one that can return infinite sequences without taking infinite memory. I've built a prototype on my side, but before moving further I would like to know whether there is interest or not.

The lazyRange would be its own top level utility at `/lazyRange.js` and essentially call `/.internals/createRange` with the parameters `(fromRight, lazy)`, with `lazy=true`. The actual implementation would be under `/.internals/lazyRange.js`, akin to baseRange. The underlying tech would be a generator function (or more performant equivalent).

Let me know if you'd like to move on with this :)

Cheers ☀️

title: _ or chain function for Lo-Dash FP
body:
Hey!

What do you think of such a `_` or `chain` function which could be exported by Lo-Dash FP:
```js
const _ = (val) => ({ pipe: (...flow) => pipe(...flow)(val)  });
```
It could improve readability for users used to Lo-Dash and to RxJS. It only wraps the pipe function (or the flow one) and would make the sense of reading more natural. 
I already use it as is but I think it might interest other people.

### Before
```js
const values = pipe(
  map(x => [x, x*2]),
  flatten,
  sortBy(x => x)
)([1, 2, 3]);
```

### After
```js
const result = _([1, 2, 3])
 .pipe(   
  map(x => [x, x*2]),
  flatten,
  sortBy(x => x)
 );
```

title: _.intersection - what should be type of param
body: As far as I understand type of parameter for `_.intersection` should be `array of arrays` not each array as parameter. IMO also would be easier to maintain with such parameter type. Please let me know what do you think guys.

title: .set nested object with dot in key
body:
Dudes, please help! i have object key properties with dots in name. I need to set nested properties, it doesnot work. set(object, 'a.b.c.d',12345) sets obj = {a: {b: {c:{d:12345}}}} ,
but i need obj = {'a.b.c.d' : 12345
anyway to do this?

title: _.template: reversed <%- %> and <%= %>
body:
[An issue in Webpack's ejs-loader](https://github.com/okonet/ejs-loader/issues/24) seems to be caused by unexpected behavior of Lodash's `_.template` function.

All resources I found on EJS templates associate `<%=` with escaped output and `<%-` with raw unescaped output. See [tj/ejs features](https://github.com/tj/ejs#features), [ejs.co docs](http://ejs.co/#docs) and their implementation: [Line 764 of ejs.js at GitHub](https://github.com/mde/ejs/blob/master/lib/ejs.js#L764).

In contrast, [Lodash's implementation](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/f73b35bb497dd8948dcfa97a6924bf5ee860d467/template.js#L74) has things other way around, associating `<%-` with escaped output and `<%=` with raw output. Lodash might have taken a wrong step here. The [_.templateSettings docs](https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.5#templateSettings) refer the default settings to follow [Embedded Ruby](https://puppet.com/docs/puppet/5.3/lang_template_erb.html#tags) and [template literals of ES2015](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Template_literals#Description) but neither has a strong opinion on the matter. Embedded Ruby associates `<%-` with whitespace slurping and ES2015 uses `String.raw` prefix for unescaped template strings.

The default syntax should follow the convention. I believe the convention has been set by tj/ejs and ejs.co.

An earlier issue https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/2829 lightly touched the problem but the purpose was rather different and was quickly closed.

title: Feature request:  "get" with function which tries to access a nested property
body:
Discovered recently this utility https://github.com/facebookincubator/idx. It seems like it would make a good addition to the get function and can be optional.

```js
idx(props, _ => _.user.friends[0].friends)
```

title: Map  with cloneDeep()
body:
I was debugging a production issue, find this:

Say an object is used as a map, but never use get() or set(). Instead, set all values like: map[key_1]=value_1

When calling cloneDeep(), it will pass all type checks as a map, but forEach() won't be able to find anything, in the end, return an empty map.

![untitled](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6863891/37535075-09042b24-291d-11e8-90b3-2283055355a7.jpg)

The old version actually handled it well.

The commit is here:
[https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/67a3fb99ef173a8beda2b414effd1e3ffb2f4f01#diff-c98b19a4629c791fefaceea05556df52](url)

body:
```js
_.sortedIndex([1, 2, 3, 3, 11, 12, 34, 2, 1, 11, 11], 5)
```
I get `4` when I run above code, is't the expected behavior?

title: FP :: trimStart & trimEnd are not working.
body:
Using the `trimStart` and `trimEnd` functions from `fp` will return wrong result.

```js
const trimEnd = require('lodash/fp/trimEnd');
const trimStart = require('lodash/fp/trimStart');

console.log( trimEnd('/', 'test//') ); // Expected `test`, but got `/` 
console.log( trimStart('//test') );  // Expected `test`, but got `/` 
```

title: _.reduce not recognized?
[Question] Is there a method to "interleave" values?
body:
For example, 
```js
const arr1 = [1, 3, 5];
const arr2 = [2, 4, 6];

lodash.interleave(arr1, arr2) // [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
```

PS: I don't know if I'm doing right by asking this right here.

title: Add `afterEvery`
Add `afterBefore`
body: This method creates a function that invokes a function,  `func`, once it's called `start` or more times until it's called `end` times.

title: _.flip on _.divide doesn't flip in lodash/fp
body:
[As noted in the docs](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/FP-Guide#exceptions-to-the-rules), `_.divide` is a method which doesn't have it's parameter order flipped from the regular lodash order. I tried using `_.flip` explicitly with divide to get a flipped form, however to my surprise I got the same result:

```
> const _ = require('lodash/fp')
undefined
> _.divide(2)(10)
0.2
> _.flip(_.divide)(2)(10)
0.2
```

When not using the autocurry form it seems to work OK:

```
> _.flip(_.divide)(2, 10)
5
```

Is this a deficiency in flip, and/or is there an alternative pattern to flip curried functions?

```
npm ls | grep lodash
│ └── lodash@4.17.4
```

title: [PR] Improve lodash.difference
body: https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/3678

title: [Suggestion] Improve lodash.difference
body:
If both arrays point to the same object, return a clean array before the comparison iteration.

They will always have the same values.

```js
import 'lodash' from 'lodash';

const arr = [1, 2, 3]

const result = lodash.difference(arr, arr)
```

title: Have an Option or a New Method that Removes First Instance of Items to Remove Using "_.without"
cloneDeep() memory leak?
body:
We used `cloneDeep()` on a (serve side) endpoint on a high traffic site for a while, and saw it loosing memory. We replaced all instances (2) of cloneDeep with the `JSON.parse(JSON.stringify())` trick, and after that the memory was stable again.

Is it possible that `cloneDeep()` has a memory leak?

Regards, J*

title: How to solve this float divide result ?
_.curry with arity ignores length on last call
body:
I've run into an issue where the last call to a function that's been curried with an explicit arity that's less than `function.length` passes the remaining arguments to the provided function. It seems like any extra arguments are still passed to the underlying function, even if they should be discarded.

Here's a simplified version of my real-world scenario:

``` js
let mapValue = _.curry(_.get, 2);
let applesToOranges = mapValue({ gala: "mandarin", fuji: "blood", envy: "navel" });
```

When I call `applesToOranges` with a value contained in the object, and I include extra arguments, everything is fine:

``` js
applesToOranges("envy", "banana") // "navel"
```

However, because the third argument to `_.get` is the default value, if the provided value is not contained inside the object, the next argument is returned.

``` js
applesToOranges("yellow", "banana") // "banana"
```

Because I passed `2` as the arity, I would expect thing function to discard the extra argument and return `undefined`.

title: [bug] _.get(obj, []) and _.get(obj, '') do not return the root object; they return undefined instead
body:
Repro:
```
_.get({a:1, b:2}, [])  // Returns 'undefined' while the root object ({a:1, b:2}) is expected.
_.get({a:1, b:2}, ['a'])  // Correctly answers 1.
_.get({a:1, b:2}, '')  // Returns 'undefined' while the root object ({a:1, b:2}) is expected.
_.get({a:1, b:2}, 'b')  // Correctly answers 2.
```

Thank you for developing such a great library!

title: lodash-es/core.js as a target for browsers

body:
We have use cases for getting the first "own" property from an object.

Is this something others might need?

title: Docs for `omitBy` not correct
body:
It says:

> The opposite of _.pickBy; this method creates an object composed of the own and inherited enumerable string keyed properties of object that predicate **doesn't return truthy for**. The predicate is invoked with two arguments: (value, key).

`doesn't return truthy for` should be changed to `does return truthy for`, OR the function is not working like explained, though I think it works correctly.

So should I update the docs and do a pull request?

title: _.assign and Object.assign  show inconsistent behavior
is it an extra judgment?
[Improvement] unescape() method does not covert ' to ' character
body:
While using lodash unescape method, I've noticed that it does not covert `'` into a ' character, but it explicitly requires the `'` codification.

The `'` codification, as specified [here](http://php.net/manual/en/function.htmlentities.php), is the result of PHP
```
// Output: Exam'ple to pa'rse
echo htmlentities( 'Exam\'ple to pa\'rse', ENT_COMPAT | ENT_HTML401 |  ENT_QUOTES);
```

I was wondering if other users have encountered my same problem and if there is a reason why only `'` is being parsed to '.

title: Floating point accuracy is lost
body:
https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/c1f805f4972843b675056b2786f1165f7db81737/multiply.js#L16

```javascript
_.multiply(8.7, 100) === 870 // false
```
is it a bug?

same thing in `add` function

```javascript
_.add(0.1, 0.2) === 0.3  // false
```

title: Object to string request.
body:
Hi, I wasn't able to find this in the docs but I think it would be very helpful to have a function that converts this object:

```
{
   foo: 'bar',
   lazy: 'dog',
}
```

into:
`foo=bar,lazy=dog`.

The parameters is the object and a separator (Example above is the comma).

This is will be helpful when doing a url parameters like `foo=bar&lazy=dog` and for the request headers like: 

```
const obj = {
    token, // abc
    secret' // def
};

const str = _.fnName(obj, ','); // this will return 'token=abc,secret=def'
const authHeader = `Oauth ${str}`;
```
Instead of hardcoding it:  

```
const authHeader = `Oauth token=${token},secret=${secret}`
```

What do you guys think?

title: Implement `getParameterByName` method
[FP] defaultTo doesn't work like explained
body:
The fp docs state that the value is always last, so we can configure the function and then use it with the value, so when doing the following with defaultTo:

```
const test = _flow(_defaultTo(something));
```

it doesn't work. When executing the flow, defaultTo gives back a wrapper instead. So can't this be used FP like?

title: `fp/update` doesn't copy Symbol props in IE
_(collection).reduce not returning wrapped collection intentionally ?
body:
Hello!

Lodash version: **4.17.5**

**The issue:**
I believe `_.reduce` should return lodash collection wrapper in case the collection is wrapped in lodash `_(collection).reduce`, but it returns the result instead. This behavior can be seen with other  functions (i.e. `_.transform` or `_.map`)

**Here is a reproduction:**
https://jsfiddle.net/AlesMenzel/n8nopvh0/17/

title: Documentation warning: _.get() with default value returning null
body:
Consider adding a warning to **_.get()** documentation saying that if null is found, _.get() will return it even though it has default value set. It might be unclear at first glance.

Example:
```
const parent = {
  child: null
}

_.get(parent, 'child', 'default')   // null
```

title: Merge behaviour with `null`/`undefined` and arrays
jQuery Examples
body: In documentation and here, on Github, there are examples of using lodash methods that are written with jQuery (those ones I've found are `before`, `debounce` and `throttle`). Isn't it better to rewrite it with native JavaScript?
